Perhaps some nights you lie awake next to
your partner. Probably, they’re not awful

5.text:
– but they are, almost certainly, a little
bit boring. After all, it’s been quite a

9.text:
long time. Sex with them is OK, but not great
in every possible way. There’s something

16.text:
so special about undressing someone for the
first time, feeling their excitement in your

21.text:
hands, and hearing them say rude words to
you in lust. But you don’t want to give

25.text:
up the relationship you are already in which
is pretty good in some key ways: maybe you

29.text:
have children or a joint home you’ve put
a lot of work into. You don’t want to lose

34.text:
everything, you just want to enjoy a few new
scenarios. At such points, like many people,

39.text:
you think: ‘What about polyamory?’ And
you feel quite brave and adventurous for going

45.text:
this far. Part of the problem is that polyamory
sounds so plausible, an ideal way out of our

51.text:
societies’ collective hypocrisy around sexual
desire. Maybe you know someone from the tennis

57.text:
club who is said to be into polyamory; they
seem normal, very sane – and extremely cheerful.

62.text:
There was an article in a magazine describing
how polyamory is becoming fashionable in Paris

67.text:
and is gaining popularity in Vancouver. Apparently
plenty of others manage it; why shouldn’t

73.text:
you? Polyamory looks like it could be, as
its advocates suggest, the future of relationships

78.text:
in general and – more urgently – of yours
in particular.

83.text:
Like many aspects of existence, polyamory
is convincing in principle. Big, general ideas

89.text:
usually are. To take another example, in principle,
many people feel it would be nice to give

94.text:
up on the rat-race in the city and relocate
to the countryside: it’s healthier, housing

99.text:
costs are lower and you’ll be able to grow
vegetables and reconnect with nature. Or,

104.text:
to take an example from politics, in principle,
many people feel that direct democracy – with

109.text:
referenda every weekend to determine every
decision – sounds like a great idea: we’d

114.text:
finally get the kind of government we want.
It happens in Switzerland so it’s obviously

118.text:
possible and technology has made it much easier
to organise. But the problem with principles

123.text:
is that they are perilously prone to leave
out the details – which is where the problems

129.text:
are located. They encourage us to forget that,
if we move to the country, we’ll be hampered

134.text:
in our plans to order sushi at short notice,
the neighbour’s tractor will wake us up

139.text:
at 5.30, things will be surprisingly expensive
and we’ll have a terrible sense of being

144.text:
left out of the party. Or (when it comes to
direct democracy), we forget the whimsical

149.text:
and terrifying nature of mass public opinion,
along with our own disinterest in the details

154.text:
of policy and the entirely exceptional nature
of Swiss society and public life.

160.text:
Things are no different with polyamory. When,
at certain times, the general principle of

164.text:
polyamory strikes us a mature and viable option
for organising our sex lives, we’d be advised

170.text:
to hold a few details in mind. We should picture
how challenging it can be when, at an orgy,

176.text:
our partner gives us a wink as they disappear
into a softly lit bedroom with two other people,

181.text:
we make a sign to join them, but are firmly
rebuffed by one of the strangers who asks

186.text:
gruffly who the weirdo with the strange underwear
might be. Hearing a partner orgasm at the

192.text:
hands of another is a complex experience.
We may forget too that, once we sign up to

198.text:
polyamory, it won’t be entirely straightforward
to locate other people who excite us deeply.

203.text:
Of course, we may have offers from types we
don’t much fancy, except it will now be

208.text:
agony to explain why we don’t want them.
However, even if we do find someone we favour,

214.text:
it may turn out their sexual tastes don’t
quite match our own. They may share our love

218.text:
of spanking but it could be harder or softer
than we would ideally prefer. Or they’ll

224.text:
love dressing as a pirate but they might refuse
to wear an eye patch, which is a deal breaker

229.text:
for us. Or they might indeed shout obscenities
but their repertoire risks being sadly unimaginative

235.text:
and their accent grating. Our partner, on
the other hand, might all the while be having

239.text:
no trouble at all locating some pretty amazing
new friends. We had assumed we’d be in demand,

245.text:
but that’s not how it could turn out. We
also tend to forget how nice it is when something

252.text:
is fully ours. As children, we never actually
liked sharing our toys, though borrowing them

258.text:
was pretty nice. When we were five, we deeply
resented if other children took the fire engine

263.text:
or started a cooking game with the miniature
kitchen. A disavowed possessive streak runs

268.text:
quite deep in many of us.
Furthermore, we’ve got a busy life, and

274.text:
polyamory takes a lot of time to organise.
Our prospective partners may be busy just

278.text:
that night we’re free or more inclined – exactly
when we had a slot – to hook up with a dentist

283.text:
who is slightly repugnant in our eyes. Despite
the freewheeling atmosphere, even in polyamory,

289.text:
there will be some surprisingly tricky and
intractable emotions to deal with. There will

294.text:
be splits, painful endings, feelings of abandonment
and moments of rage. We’ll be exposed to

299.text:
the inner tribulations of a great many people
rather than just those of a single well-charted

305.text:
spouse. Certain partners will burst into uncontrollable
sobs and talk urgently of their mothers – when

311.text:
all we were looking for was a rapid sexual
thrill. Others will, as we stand at the bedside

316.text:
with a whip or a mask, accuse us of selfishness,
pretend to read a magazine and refuse to explain

322.text:
what’s wrong. There’s no dispute at all
that polyamory will work very well for some people;

328.text:
but like many very alluring ideas, that doesn’t
mean it will work for us. Mostly likely, if

334.text:
we become polyamorous, we will once again
encounter almost all of the problems we’d

340.text:
once known so well in monogamy – only far more
